greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Aliquot predecessors with the largest values.
comment: Find each node's predecessors in aliquot sequences and choose the largest predecessor.
Climb the aliquot trees on shortest paths (see A135245 = Climb the aliquot trees on thickest branches).
The sequence starts at offset 2, since all primes satisfy sigma(n)-n = 1. - _Michel Marcus_, Nov 11 2014
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000 (terms 2..150 from Ophir Spector)
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles. [Broken link]
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles. [Via Internet Archive Wayback-Machine]
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles. [Cached copy, pdf file only]
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Aliquot sequence.
example: a(25) = 143 since 25 has 3 predecessors (95,119,143), 143 being the largest. a(5) = 0 since it has no predecessors (see Untouchables - A005114).
mathematica: seq[max_] := Module[{s = Table[0, {n, 1, max}], i}, Do[If[(i = DivisorSigma[1, n] - n) <= max, s[[i]] = Max[s[[i]], n]], {n, 2, (max - 1)^2}]; Rest @ s]; seq[50]
program: (PARI) lista(nn) = {for (n=2, nn, k = (n-1)^2; while(k && (sigma(k)-k != n), k--); print1(k, ", "););} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Nov 11 2014
results.author: Ophir Spector (ospectoro(AT)yahoo.com), Nov 25 2007
ext: a(1)=0 removed and offset set to 2 by _Michel Marcus_, Nov 11 2014
